ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Reading papers and presenting/talking about them. Also using an ML library on a dataset, and then writing a report on what you did.
Writing reports
machine learning applications in a variety of industries
General awareness of ML methods.
A tiny bit of knowledge in a massive range of areas - robotics, environmental science, econ, medicine, etc - and an example of how each of these fields use machine learning.
a little bit of everything
Current topics in Applied ML, presentation skills
I learned about how ML can be used in a wide variety of researchx
sota algorithms and applications for ml
I was able to learn how to read ML papers and understand them independently, as well as learn about new ML advancements from top speakers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed this class, but I think you get what you put into it. The guest lectures and student presentations can be interesting, but require you to be there/pay attention to actually learn anything. I'm not really sure how you could improve the class without losing the research part of it though.

Very disorganized. You hardly learn anything from student presentations. But for a course that is so disorganized it is also unreasonably strict on grading and late day policies. The teaching staff is unresponsive and makes unreasonable requirements.
very interesting guest speakers
Very un-engaging, boring, and most of the class was student presentations which seemed like a waste of a class.

It's very easy to skate through this course without learning anything - if a student is interested, however, there is a great deal to learn from! The guest lecturers were all great, and most of the student presentations were super informative as well.

strengths - allows you to learn a little bit of everything in ML, hear interesting research topics through student presentations and project
weakness - the expectations and grading rubric on assignments were vague and the TFs were very harsh when grading and would take away points from every minor error, the professor makes it seem like it is a chill class but towards the end of the semester, they post your grades that are very harsh
Guest lectures are very insightful and can be better organized.

The guest lectures were really cool and provided valuable exposure to what people are working on in ML, both on the academia and industry sides. Half of the class comprised of student presentations, which is very chill and you are exposed to a lot of different papers.

Strengths: gut, easy to add on as a 5th class. The week to week workload is extremely low. 

Weaknesses: not much instruction is given on the term assignments. its hard to stay engaged in the class, because all of classtime is spent listening to other students' presentations.

I would like the professor to teach more materials and less time for student presentation. And I don't like that we are forced to ask questions for participation grade. To encourage participation, we should have more options like asking and answering in ED discussion, summarizing what we learned, etc. And I would prefer the final project to be group project.

Cool subjects, and guest lectures were great 
Should probably tone down the number of student presentations and somehow incorporate more teaching
The power to control how much you learn is a strength. The lack of group projects was excellent. Excluding graduate students from paper presentations would be ideal to save time on presentations,.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're interested in machine learning research, or currently doing machine learning research, then yes. If that doesn't interest you though, you probably won't get anything out of the class.

I would not recommend. Though the guest lectures are interesting at first, once the student presentations start you don't get much from the class. The assignments require large amount of work with no help from the teaching staff.
yes the guest lecturers are great
No, this was the worst class I've taken at Yale. Not structured at all.

If you - like myself - have a computer science background and are trying to explore scientific ways of applying it, I think this course would be a great fit. If you study a different area, I don't think this course works well as a first exposure to ML; a good bit of preliminary knowledge is needed to get much out of even the student presentations.
yes and no: if you do not care about your grade or CR/D/F, then yes, but if you do, then take another course
Yes, it would be a good seminar course in Applied ML
Take it if you want a low workload CS elective and are remotely interested in ML.

If you are interested in a CS gut, this is a good class to take. There is one coding project that is done independently, as well as papers and presentations. However my engagement with this class was really low. The class format wasn't conducive to learning but I was able to research more on ML topics that I was personally interested in.
yes
It was a chill credit where I learned vaguely about machine learning techniques but not in depth. Up to you whether thats worth
I recommend it for a low-workload course where you get to see interesting guest speakers and get exposure to interesting parts of machine learning that you weren't familiar with.
Yes, this class is a great way to get an introduction to a large variety of applications for machine learning through guest and student presentations.
I would recommend this to another student if they were truly interested in making a contribution to the ML field while still being a class.

extras.title: CPSC 482 01/CPSC 582 01 - Current Topics in Applied ML
